canonical_explanation.text: Inequalities in triangles establish important relationships between sides and angles. The theorem states that in any triangle, the side opposite to the larger angle is longer, and conversely, the angle opposite to the longer side is larger. The triangle inequality theorem states that the sum of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than the third side. Additionally, an exterior angle of a triangle is always greater than either of the non-adjacent interior angles.

The difference of any two sides of a triangle is always less than the third side
An exterior angle of a triangle is greater than either of the interior opposite angles
The exterior angle of a triangle equals the sum of the two interior opposite angles
